text:
Good morning everyone.   Having landed some new contracts we're expanding our Dev team. I'm looking for two full stack or frontend only JS developers with experience of MVC frameworks, preferably Ember.js. This is a role suitable for someone with 2-4 years of relevant experience, not necessarily commercial. You need to be able to hit the ground running on day 1. 

Based at Mornington Crescent we have a small fun team, working on digital media and IoT, in JS, C# and C++, on PC, Raspberry Pi and embedded devices. 

The first project you'd be working on are the scoreboards at Lord's cricket ground - a 280 sq m Ember app! We also work for a film studio in LA, amongst others. Very high profile customers means interesting and challenging problems to solve. It's never boring. 

Send CVs to me at <mailto:Bryan.crotaz@silvercurve.co.uk|Bryan.crotaz@silvercurve.co.uk> or pm me here for a chat
<@U04TVTLQ8>: it might be worth posting that in the <#C03U3R002> channel also, as it might get lost in general soon when conversations start to pick up
it's awesome to see more and more companies picking up Ember :slightly_smiling_face:
agreed
more and more "big apps" built on Ember
^ that as well :slightly_smiling_face:
imo Ember _is_ for big apps
bigish
big, long-lived apps (both in terms of how many years they are in service and how many hours they spend open in the user’s browser)
with big teams
but not so friendly for "islands of richness"
I agree
never worked on a small app/island of richness
cant really comment on it
tbh, our only issue with Ember is optimising it. We really haven't found the best approach yet
other than that, Ember is always my go-to choice for any project I work on, small or big
<@U0C5RUAQ4>: you mean where you hit rendering bottlenecks?
not really, rendering times are generally fine, except if you have a ton of links which we solved using the `href-to` helper.
I'm more referring to the size of the javascript files as you add ember-addons
ah
you add one addon which depend on 10 others, which depend on others, so your vendor file instantly jumps like 100-200kb just by adding a simple addon
so for <http://trouva.com|trouva.com> at least I try and depend on as less ember addons as possible
yeah, I have a similar philosophy
very picky about addons
true on Rails projects too though
I wouldn't say the same for our content management system though. :neutral_face:
a few popular gems and the size of the Rails app in memory balloons to 500MB
isn’t this just the general issue of npm
you install 1 dependency and it carries 300 with it
yeah, it’s definitely not ideal
true on any project
libraries are good when necessary
<https://twitter.com/m1sp/status/739653937108647936>

attachments.fallback: <https://twitter.com/m1sp|@m1sp>: In today's nodejs fun... here is my single required package, and the ~500 dependency tree modules it really installs <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/CkPHOrvUYAAzr4h.jpg>
attachments.text: In today's nodejs fun... here is my single required package, and the ~500 dependency tree modules it really installs <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/CkPHOrvUYAAzr4h.jpg>

text: not before :wink:
lol there we go
:facepalm:
the weird thing is that lodash covers most of the dependencies ppl tend to install
why don’t more npm modules just depend on lodash
generally people don't want the whole of lodash, but with lodash v4, people will probably start using it
because you can import only a single function :smile:
<@U0C5RUAQ4>: see above, that is what you get when you don’t want the whole of lodash, we could have avoided that altogether
<https://twitter.com/m1sp/status/739662828202659840>

attachments.fallback: <https://twitter.com/m1sp|@m1sp>: <https://twitter.com/mister_borogove|@mister_borogove> alas, no. though we do have the joy of both "isarray" and "is-arrayish"
attachments.text: <https://twitter.com/mister_borogove|@mister_borogove> alas, no. though we do have the joy of both "isarray" and "is-arrayish"

text: I vaguely remember a proposal to include lodash with Ember
and the core team was open to it
<@U0ASPMFPS>: I would say that's an extreme example though.
I guess, but when comparing it to my PHP project that does more and only have 15 dependencies, its a bit crazy
one day Javascript will have a standard library
maybe there should be a biased npm search directory
you search for `isarray` and get only `lodash` in the results
the problem is when you start installing frontend dependencies, you're doomed
if it's dependencies that are on the backend side of things, then you're generally ok. you shouldn't see much of a difference is speed, the more dependencies you add
yeah true, my SailsJS project only has 21 dependencies and it does a lot
so yeah its definitely a frontend thing
I take that back, opened my FeatherJS project and have over 230 dependencies
I definitely have Rails projects where the dependency graphs are terrifying
would love to see that :smile:
haha, I’ve probably got the graphviz rendering in an old email somewhere
isarrayish
loool
#engineering
#good-enough :tm:
dependencies are like CSS, as soon as you get to the point where it’s time-consuming to find what tools you already have available to you, all bets are off
definetly
hmm, haven't thought of it this way before
interesting way to look at it
:jamie: :tm:
nuff said
:copyright:
